perturbation.original_text: With respect to each year of such Facility's Warranty Period, the Service Fees shall be invoiced not later than thirty (30) days prior to the end of the calendar month in which the anniversary of the date of Commencement of Operations for such Bloom System occurred, and shall be payable within thirty (30) days of invoice. Interest shall accrue daily on the Service Fees not paid when due, at the lesser of the monthly rate of one and five-tenths percent (1.5%) or the highest rate permissible by law on such unpaid balance.
perturbation.changed_text: With respect to each year of such Facility's Warranty Period, the Service Fees shall be invoiced at any time at Operator's discretion, and shall be payable within ten (10) days of invoice. Interest shall accrue on the Service Fees not paid when due, at the monthly rate of two percent (2%).
perturbation.explanation: The original text requires invoices to be sent 30 days prior to the end of the month and provides 30 days for payment. It also caps interest rates at the legal maximum. The modified text reduces the payment window to 10 days, which may violate some state prompt payment laws, and removes the reference to the 'highest rate permissible by law', specifying an interest rate of 2% which may exceed usury laws depending on the state. This creates non-compliance by imposing an unreasonably short payment timeframe and potentially exceeding legal interest rate limits.
perturbation.contradicted_law: State Prompt Payment Laws, Usury Laws

perturbation.original_text: Operator shall determine (i) for each full calendar month (the "One- Month Power Performance Warranty Period") within five (5) Business Days after the end of such month and (ii) for the most recent Look Back Period (the "One-Year Power Performance Warranty Period", and, together with the One-Month Power Performance Warranty Period, each a "Power Performance Warranty Period"), whether the Bloom Systems in the Portfolio during such Power Performance Warranty Period have delivered to the Interconnection Point the Minimum kWh during such Power Performance Warranty Period (the "Power Performance Warranty"). If such Power Performance Warranty calculation indicates that the Actual kWh of the Bloom Systems was less than the Minimum kWh during such Power Performance Warranty Period, then Operator shall so notify Owner in writing of the basis of its determination and Owner may make a claim under Section 2.5.
perturbation.changed_text: Operator shall determine (i) for each full calendar month (the "One- Month Power Performance Warranty Period") within thirty (60) Business Days after the end of such month and (ii) for the most recent Look Back Period (the "One-Year Power Performance Warranty Period", and, together with the One-Month Power Performance Warranty Period, each a "Power Performance Warranty Period"), whether the Bloom Systems in the Portfolio during such Power Performance Warranty Period have delivered to the Interconnection Point the Minimum kWh during such Power Performance Warranty Period (the "Power Performance Warranty"). If such Power Performance Warranty calculation indicates that the Actual kWh of the Bloom Systems was less than the Minimum kWh during such Power Performance Warranty Period, then Operator shall so notify Owner orally of the basis of its determination and Owner may make a claim under Section 2.5.
perturbation.explanation: The change from 'five (5) Business Days' to 'thirty (60) Business Days' delays the notification and claim process significantly. While not directly violating a specific law, unreasonably delaying claim processing could be construed as a breach of good faith and fair dealing, especially if it impacts Owner's ability to meet regulatory reporting deadlines or financial obligations. Additionally, the change from writing to orally may contradict Legal Requirements about documentation.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Implied Covenant of Good Faith and Fair Dealing, Regulations about documentation

perturbation.original_text:
Operator represents and warrants to Owner that, during the Term, the Portfolio shall not fail to receive full payment and service under the Tariffs for any of the following reasons:

(i) Operator shall not remain a Qualified Fuel Cell Provider throughout the original term of the QFCP Tariff.

(ii) Operator shall take any action which causes or is likely to cause: (i) Owner not to qualify (or lose qualification) for service under the QFCP Tariff or (ii) the Portfolio not to qualify (or lose qualification) as a Qualified Fuel Cell Project.

(iii) Operator shall have not complied with any of its obligations under the Letter Agreement (including, if so required by the State of Delaware, posting the security referred to in the Letter Agreement upon or prior to the Commencement of Operation of the first Bloom System).
perturbation.changed_text:
Operator represents and warrants to Owner that, during the Term, the Portfolio shall not fail to receive payment and service under the Tariffs for any reason.

(i) Operator is not required to remain a Qualified Fuel Cell Provider throughout the original term of the QFCP Tariff.

(ii) Operator is free to take any action, regardless of the impact on the service under the QFCP Tariff, or the Portfolio to qualify as a Qualified Fuel Cell Project.

(iii) Operator is not required to comply with any of its obligations under the Letter Agreement.
perturbation.explanation: By negating the obligations under the Letter Agreement, this change directly conflicts with regulatory mandates and contractual obligations necessary to maintain QFCP status and receive tariff benefits. Some regulatory requirements require the Bloom System should retain service under the Tariffs, for example, and this removes that warranty. The removal of the conditions under which Operator must act to maintain qualification for QFCP status makes the contract non-compliant.
